body: How do you always find so much stuff to post? You make like 5 good posts every half hour and I rarely even find one or two things to post in a whole day. I assume that seeking content or information is just yet another natural talent I don't have, but is there anything specific you're doing? And if so, what led you to find out how?
body_html: How do you always find so much stuff to post? You make like 5 good posts every half hour and I rarely even find one or two things to post in a whole day. I assume that seeking content or information is just yet another natural talent I don't have, but is there anything specific you're doing? And if so, what led you to find out how?

post.title: MYSTERY as DOJ & FBI Land a 757 Jet in Clinton's Hometown Little Rock, Arkansas; Load It With Boxes & Documents – True Pundit

author.bio: GM of +Clownworld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +Prolife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others
author.bio_html: GM of +ClownWorld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +ProLife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others

body:
Lol thank you. 

It’s a conscious effort. 

Half of what’s political I post usually comes from the collective gathering skills of the anons on Q’s board. 24/7 people are researching and gathering information, it’s gathered in mega threads, anything special is labeled “notable” and is made into a list at the top of the next mega thread. These mega threads are called “breads” and they are baked by anonymous volunteers. A bread gets baked about every 2 hours. I don’t post everything I see there. Coming across Q and the anons was sort of luck, but I think I would have found them at some point. 

The other half of what’s political I post comes from my own regular sources of information. I regularly check a number of newsites, the DOJ, ICE newsrooms, the White House news, and a number of YouTube political commentary shows I follow and regularly discover etc. I learned how to do this on the_donald. When I saw where people were posting stuff, I got curious for myself, found and started posting content myself to inform other people. 

I make an effort to combat the msm narrative lies. 

The same for non political stuff, I’ve deliberately gone out to find content. Some of this I didn’t do before Ruqqus, but I wanted share light and positive things to counter act negativity. I’m making an effort to shape the available content on Ruqqus to have true and positive content. It’s important to the future of our country. 

I’m a very information thirsty person. I like learning, I like knowing what’s going on. Over time I’ve developed better researching skills to find information. 

You can do this too and I recommend it. Being able to research is a good skill. A tip: I’ve found more information from connections and recommendations in other content and people than in searches. Searches are often highly curated, we know as much from various big tech leaks. 

Tools like reverse image lookup are useful for finding sources. 

If you can find the primary source.

body:
That covers the news and politics, but what about all the other general content, memes, pics, non-political news, meta, media, etc?

Regardless, for both types of content I have the same attitude as you but I *never*, and I repeat, ***NEVER*** manage to come across anything worthwhile, no matter how hard I look for things. All I can find is the top few results from Google and that's it. Like everything else in my life, I've just given up by now because I literally *can't* do it. I know of no good places to find things, I can't ever find any. But for some people it's just so effortless, as is everything else in life.

Regardless, for both types of content I have the same attitude as you but I never, and I repeat, NEVER manage to come across anything worthwhile, no matter how hard I look for things. All I can find is the top few results from Google and that's it. Like everything else in my life, I've just given up by now because I literally can't do it. I know of no good places to find things, I can't ever find any. But for some people it's just so effortless, as is everything else in life.

post.title: MYSTERY as DOJ & FBI Land a 757 Jet in Clinton's Hometown Little Rock, Arkansas; Load It With Boxes & Documents – True Pundit

author.bio: GM of +Clownworld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +Prolife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others
author.bio_html: GM of +ClownWorld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +ProLife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others

body:
Like I said it’s really not effortless. It’s something I learned how to do and put effort into. 

I’d say maybe 1% of content I post regularly comes from searching for it with the search bar. But the sites I post to upliftingnews, I did find through search, but now I pull from them manually by checking everyday. 

Sometimes I just refresh the YouTube front page algorithm, sometimes I hop from recommended video to recommended video. Sometimes I return to a video just to check the recommended section. Anything I find interesting on YouTube I subscribe to. If it’s really interesting YouTube won’t show stuff I’m following to me and I have to check manually. 

Maybe pick a specific subject and I’ll teach you how I find things.

Maybe pick a specific subject and I’ll teach you how I find things.

Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
I don't think the subject matters. You obviously know how to find everything for all subjects, so it seems unrelated to the subject. I can never find any good sites through search either. It's of course another catch-22, you can't find the sites to find stuff on if the search is bad and you can't find those sites in the first place. Oh, about catch-22s, in my whole life I've never managed to get out of one no matter how hard I try, but some people always do if they try. It can't be just pure luck because this "luck" stays consistently the same for each person all the time. It's probably a matter of some people having more intuitiveness, which I am seriously lacking with, and that's probably not something I'll ever be able to change. And having to rely on other people to accomplish everything for me just plain *sucks*.

You could teach me how to find things in one subject but it would only be useful for that specific subject, exactly for the parts I was taught, and would have very little possibility for improvement. I know this because others have taught me how to find things in a few subjects in the past, and this same thing has happened in fields other than finding stuff too. The only way to adaptively develop the same skills would be to find out *how you learned* to find things and repeat the same thing myself, which of course like most of my goals is impossible for me--I can copy other people half as well, but when it comes to developing anything of my own ability it just doesn't happen.

If you want I suppose you can teach me about news stories, since that's your expertise. And with that, how do you always 100% of the time manage to be the first one to post it? On the rare occasion I do find something interesting I usually don't even have to look to know that someone else already posted it.

I know this because others have taught me how to find things in a few subjects in the past, and this same thing has happened in fields other than finding stuff too. The only way to adaptively develop the same skills would be to find out how you learned to find things and repeat the same thing myself, which of course like most of my goals is impossible for me--I can copy other people half as well, but when it comes to developing anything of my own ability it just doesn't happen.

If you want I suppose you can teach me about news stories, since that's your expertise. And with that, how do you always 100% of the time manage to be the first one to post it? On the rare occasion I do find something interesting I usually don't even have to look to know that someone else already posted it.

post.title: MYSTERY as DOJ & FBI Land a 757 Jet in Clinton's Hometown Little Rock, Arkansas; Load It With Boxes & Documents – True Pundit

author.bio: GM of +Clownworld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +Prolife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others
author.bio_html: GM of +ClownWorld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +ProLife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others

body:
So maybe it’ll help if I add this concept. There are two ways I receive information: active and passive. Passive are things already on my radar, things I subscribe to, things I check regularly, things I see in passing. Active is me exploring. Me searching for new information and cultivating a sense of continual scholarship. This is reading books and watching leactures/talk shows/conspiracy videos. I say I want to learn about law and then I go find ways to learn about law. 

I am on here periodically basically all day and am checking/updating myself on information all day. That’s probably why I’m first. I’m the most engaged and zealous. 

So finding the News. I’m constantly adapting this myself. 

All of these I consider “passive”:

The first thing I check is this:

https://wearethene.ws/

It’s aggregator that pulls the notables from the breads on 8kun I was talking about before. It’s currently broken this week, but I’m hoping they fix it soon. 

When I want to check manually, I go the clearnet link:

https://8kun.top/qresearch/catalog.html

The Q Research thread closest to the top is the active and most current bread. I turn off the images in the top right corner so I don’t have to see NSFW/NSFL images. 

Next I check Disrn:

https://disrn.com/

Disrn is my current favorite news site. I learned about Disrn when the creator of the Babylon bee announced he was leaving them to start a news site. 

Then I check:

https://thefederalist.com/blog/

https://pjmedia.com/

https://www.redstate.com/

https://townhall.com/

https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/

https://rantingly.com/

https://www.justice.gov/news

https://www.ice.gov/news/all

https://www.whitehouse.gov/news/

https://notthebee.com/

I’ve found these from other posting them, being referenced by other things, or searching for them. About every few months I do a search for conservative news outlets or aggregators. 

Then I see what my conservative political commentators are talking about etc. Usually a wrap or further discussion of stuff that happened earlier in the week. Good for people who aren’t active in seeing this news. It’s fun/relatable to watch and good for sharing. 

https://www.youtube.com/c/markdice

https://www.youtube.com/c/NextNewsNetwork

https://www.youtube.com/c/BenSwann

https://www.youtube.com/user/PrisonPlanetLive

https://www.youtube.com/c/TheOfficerTatum

https://www.youtube.com/user/kevinellerbe

https://www.youtube.com/c/prageruniversity

https://www.youtube.com/c/oann

Also White House has events everyday: https://www.youtube.com/c/WhiteHouse

Now I don’t always watch/check everything. Some days I watch/listen more and some days I don’t. Depends on my mood. 

Now digesting that’s info is another component. Dealing with fake news. Discerning truth means finding sources. Since I am aware of the general political landscape. I know when people say “Trump said this”, I can check the White House for videos of him at events (and probably I already watched). Which means I’ll know if he said and if it’s consistent with his daily character. If it’s about an incident, I may have already heard about it from the anons. While I don’t have Twitter, I can still search it. I will search with hashtags. Or you can use reverse image lookup for original sources. When people talk about a document, I’ll go find it. Sometimes I just copy and paste quotes into search to see where else they pop up. If it’s like an incident, I’ll search YouTube for videos of it or Bitchute. 

But as you can see I have a wholistic net that covers things for different angles and different entities connect. You absorb certain meta information by engaging with it. 

I used to have other methods as well. I used to be on the_donald on reddit, I used to be an active and regular member of that discord as well and people would drop info and other discords. But as I’ve gotten more independent in sourcing my info, I don’t need some of them. Sometimes getting cut off from sources means finding new ways to find information because you are forced to. 

Other days I pivot into active exploring. This where I explore the edges of what I know and further my knowledge in general or fix gaps in my information net, like finding more conservative women perspectives. This is also conspiracy related content and political, philosophical, theological theory. 

And some days I focus more on non-political content. 

Thoughts, questions?

Let There Be Light
guild.name: WhereWeGo1WeGoAll

parent.body:
I don't think the subject matters. You obviously know how to find everything for all subjects, so it seems unrelated to the subject. I can never find any good sites through search either. It's of course another catch-22, you can't find the sites to find stuff on if the search is bad and you can't find those sites in the first place. Oh, about catch-22s, in my whole life I've never managed to get out of one no matter how hard I try, but some people always do if they try. It can't be just pure luck because this "luck" stays consistently the same for each person all the time. It's probably a matter of some people having more intuitiveness, which I am seriously lacking with, and that's probably not something I'll ever be able to change. And having to rely on other people to accomplish everything for me just plain *sucks*.

You could teach me how to find things in one subject but it would only be useful for that specific subject, exactly for the parts I was taught, and would have very little possibility for improvement. I know this because others have taught me how to find things in a few subjects in the past, and this same thing has happened in fields other than finding stuff too. The only way to adaptively develop the same skills would be to find out *how you learned* to find things and repeat the same thing myself, which of course like most of my goals is impossible for me--I can copy other people half as well, but when it comes to developing anything of my own ability it just doesn't happen.

If you want I suppose you can teach me about news stories, since that's your expertise. And with that, how do you always 100% of the time manage to be the first one to post it? On the rare occasion I do find something interesting I usually don't even have to look to know that someone else already posted it.

I know this because others have taught me how to find things in a few subjects in the past, and this same thing has happened in fields other than finding stuff too. The only way to adaptively develop the same skills would be to find out how you learned to find things and repeat the same thing myself, which of course like most of my goals is impossible for me--I can copy other people half as well, but when it comes to developing anything of my own ability it just doesn't happen.

If you want I suppose you can teach me about news stories, since that's your expertise. And with that, how do you always 100% of the time manage to be the first one to post it? On the rare occasion I do find something interesting I usually don't even have to look to know that someone else already posted it.

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
I don't know how you do *all* of that just by being on "periodically". It'd take me half a day just to go through all that *once* (and don't think I've never tried before either). I'm also not sure how the heck you discovered all those aggregators, because I'm quite sure Google wouldn't display them.

The other issue is, I can robotically replicate this exact process probably half as well as you can do it, but it's only useful for this specific topic (don't worry, I'll certainly use it, so you didn't do all that typing for nothing). What I need more is to figure out how to develop these methods myself, as well as finding sources/useful tools on my own, so I can apply it to other areas. You and a few others know how to do that, but I don't and never have. As such, as soon as I go to a different topic or even just try to find more sources, I'm completely and hopelessly lost again. And I don't want to have to ask you or one of my friends to take the time to come up with a process for me for every single topic. I'm not talented mentally so almost everything comes very difficult to me. I can copycat even very complex processes but when it comes to thinking outside the box for myself I can hardly manage even the slightest bit of it. But this is pretty much just me complaining at this point.

You and a few others know how to do that, but I don't and never have. As such, as soon as I go to a different topic or even just try to find more sources, I'm completely and hopelessly lost again. I'm not talented mentally so almost everything comes very difficult to me. I can copycat even very complex processes but when it comes to thinking outside the box for myself I can hardly manage even the slightest bit of it. But this is pretty much just me complaining at this point.

parent.body:
So maybe it’ll help if I add this concept. There are two ways I receive information: active and passive. Passive are things already on my radar, things I subscribe to, things I check regularly, things I see in passing. Active is me exploring. Me searching for new information and cultivating a sense of continual scholarship. This is reading books and watching leactures/talk shows/conspiracy videos. I say I want to learn about law and then I go find ways to learn about law. 

I am on here periodically basically all day and am checking/updating myself on information all day. That’s probably why I’m first. I’m the most engaged and zealous. 

So finding the News. I’m constantly adapting this myself. 

All of these I consider “passive”:

The first thing I check is this:

https://wearethene.ws/

It’s aggregator that pulls the notables from the breads on 8kun I was talking about before. It’s currently broken this week, but I’m hoping they fix it soon. 

When I want to check manually, I go the clearnet link:

https://8kun.top/qresearch/catalog.html

The Q Research thread closest to the top is the active and most current bread. I turn off the images in the top right corner so I don’t have to see NSFW/NSFL images. 

Next I check Disrn:

https://disrn.com/

Disrn is my current favorite news site. I learned about Disrn when the creator of the Babylon bee announced he was leaving them to start a news site. 

Then I check:

https://thefederalist.com/blog/

https://pjmedia.com/

https://www.redstate.com/

https://townhall.com/

https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/

https://rantingly.com/

https://www.justice.gov/news

https://www.ice.gov/news/all

https://www.whitehouse.gov/news/

https://notthebee.com/

I’ve found these from other posting them, being referenced by other things, or searching for them. About every few months I do a search for conservative news outlets or aggregators. 

Then I see what my conservative political commentators are talking about etc. Usually a wrap or further discussion of stuff that happened earlier in the week. Good for people who aren’t active in seeing this news. It’s fun/relatable to watch and good for sharing. 

https://www.youtube.com/c/markdice

https://www.youtube.com/c/NextNewsNetwork

https://www.youtube.com/c/BenSwann

https://www.youtube.com/user/PrisonPlanetLive

https://www.youtube.com/c/TheOfficerTatum

https://www.youtube.com/user/kevinellerbe

https://www.youtube.com/c/prageruniversity

https://www.youtube.com/c/oann

Also White House has events everyday: https://www.youtube.com/c/WhiteHouse

Now I don’t always watch/check everything. Some days I watch/listen more and some days I don’t. Depends on my mood. 

Now digesting that’s info is another component. Dealing with fake news. Discerning truth means finding sources. Since I am aware of the general political landscape. I know when people say “Trump said this”, I can check the White House for videos of him at events (and probably I already watched). Which means I’ll know if he said and if it’s consistent with his daily character. If it’s about an incident, I may have already heard about it from the anons. While I don’t have Twitter, I can still search it. I will search with hashtags. Or you can use reverse image lookup for original sources. When people talk about a document, I’ll go find it. Sometimes I just copy and paste quotes into search to see where else they pop up. If it’s like an incident, I’ll search YouTube for videos of it or Bitchute. 

But as you can see I have a wholistic net that covers things for different angles and different entities connect. You absorb certain meta information by engaging with it. 

I used to have other methods as well. I used to be on the_donald on reddit, I used to be an active and regular member of that discord as well and people would drop info and other discords. But as I’ve gotten more independent in sourcing my info, I don’t need some of them. Sometimes getting cut off from sources means finding new ways to find information because you are forced to. 

Other days I pivot into active exploring. This where I explore the edges of what I know and further my knowledge in general or fix gaps in my information net, like finding more conservative women perspectives. This is also conspiracy related content and political, philosophical, theological theory. 

And some days I focus more on non-political content. 

Thoughts, questions?

post.title: MYSTERY as DOJ & FBI Land a 757 Jet in Clinton's Hometown Little Rock, Arkansas; Load It With Boxes & Documents – True Pundit

author.bio: GM of +Clownworld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +Prolife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others
author.bio_html: GM of +ClownWorld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +ProLife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others

body:
Yes, the information landscape of the net is changing. Censorship is making it harder. And that's why I don't mind taking the time to personally recommend information. I've gotten good recommendations from others. And I don't usually check all those things in one day. Though I actually forgot a few lol and this isn't the only subject I look at a day. 

It's true different industries or spheres of knowledge are different, but there's some overlap in the way you can discover information. 

And to be fair it's taken me a while to learn how to do this. I started getting into politics during the 2018 mid terms and here am now. I had a hard time finding my first job. Took me about 6 months. But while I wasn't looking for a job, I spent the rest of my time learning about politics. I learned and absorbed a lot of information and now I am able to investigate and share myself. It was a difficult time, but I'm thankful for how it helped me learn. 

I did pray for wisdom and knowledge though lol I think God answered my prayer. 

Doing worry too much and keep fumbling around. Finding good information is hard, but it's also worth the effort. And you're welcome to ask me more anytime.
